segment.source: Lock down Windows 10 to specific apps (Windows 10)
segment.target: Lock down Windows 10 to specific apps (Windows 10)

segment.source: Learn how to configure a device running Windows 10 Enterprise or Windows 10 Education so that users can only run a few specific apps.
segment.target: Learn how to configure a device running Windows 10 Enterprise or Windows 10 Education so that users can only run a few specific apps.

segment.source: Lock down Windows 10 to specific apps
segment.target: Lock down Windows 10 to specific apps

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: Learn how to configure a device running Windows 10 Enterprise or Windows 10 Education so that users can only run a few specific apps.
segment.target: Learn how to configure a device running Windows 10 Enterprise or Windows 10 Education so that users can only run a few specific apps.

segment.source: The result is similar to a kiosk device, but with multiple apps available.
segment.target: The result is similar to a kiosk device, but with multiple apps available.

segment.source: For example, you might set up a library computer so that users can search the catalog and browse the Internet, but can't run any other apps or change computer settings.
segment.target: For example, you might set up a library computer so that users can search the catalog and browse the Internet, but can't run any other apps or change computer settings.

segment.source: You can restrict users to a specific set of apps on a device running Windows 10 Enterprise or Windows 10 Education by using AppLocker.
segment.target: You can restrict users to a specific set of apps on a device running Windows 10 Enterprise or Windows 10 Education by using AppLocker.

segment.source: AppLocker rules specify which apps are allowed to run on the device.
segment.target: AppLocker rules specify which apps are allowed to run on the device.

segment.source: AppLocker rules are organized into collections based on file format.
segment.target: AppLocker rules are organized into collections based on file format.

segment.source: If no AppLocker rules for a specific rule collection exist, all files with that file format are allowed to run.
segment.target: If no AppLocker rules for a specific rule collection exist, all files with that file format are allowed to run.

segment.source: However, when an AppLocker rule for a specific rule collection is created, only the files explicitly allowed in a rule are permitted to run.
segment.target: However, when an AppLocker rule for a specific rule collection is created, only the files explicitly allowed in a rule are permitted to run.

segment.source: For more information, see How AppLocker works.
segment.target: For more information, see How AppLocker works.

segment.source: This topic describes how to lock down apps on a local device.
segment.target: This topic describes how to lock down apps on a local device.

segment.source: You can also use AppLocker to set rules for applications in a domain by using Group Policy.
segment.target: You can also use AppLocker to set rules for applications in a domain by using Group Policy.

segment.source: install create lockdown customize
segment.target: install create lockdown customize

segment.source: Install apps
segment.target: Install apps

segment.source: First, install the desired apps on the device for the target user account(s).
segment.target: First, install the desired apps on the device for the target user account(s).

segment.source: This works for both Store and Win32.
segment.target: This works for both Store and Win32.

segment.source: For Store apps, you must log on as that user for the app to install.
segment.target: For Store apps, you must log on as that user for the app to install.

segment.source: For Win32 you can install an app for all users without logging on to the particular account.
segment.target: For Win32 you can install an app for all users without logging on to the particular account.

segment.source: Use AppLocker to set rules for apps
segment.target: Use AppLocker to set rules for apps

segment.source: After you install the desired apps, set up AppLocker rules to only allow specific apps, and block everything else.
segment.target: After you install the desired apps, set up AppLocker rules to only allow specific apps, and block everything else.

segment.source: Run Local Security Policy (secpol.msc) as an administrator.
segment.target: Run Local Security Policy (secpol.msc) as an administrator.

segment.source: Go to Security SettingsApplication Control PoliciesAppLocker, and select Configure rule enforcement.
segment.target: Go to Security SettingsApplication Control PoliciesAppLocker, and select Configure rule enforcement.

segment.source: configure rule enforcement
segment.target: configure rule enforcement

segment.source: Check Configured under Executable rules, and then click OK.
segment.target: Check Configured under Executable rules, and then click OK.

segment.source: Right-click Executable Rules and then click Automatically generate rules.
segment.target: Right-click Executable Rules and then click Automatically generate rules.

segment.source: automatically generate rules
segment.target: automatically generate rules

segment.source: Select the folder that contains the apps that you want to permit, or select C: to analyze all apps.
segment.target: Select the folder that contains the apps that you want to permit, or select C: to analyze all apps.

segment.source: Type a name to identify this set of rules, and then click Next.
segment.target: Type a name to identify this set of rules, and then click Next.

segment.source: On the Rule Preferences page, click Next.
segment.target: On the Rule Preferences page, click Next.

segment.source: Be patient, it might take awhile to generate the rules.
segment.target: Be patient, it might take awhile to generate the rules.

segment.source: On the Review Rules page, click Create.
segment.target: On the Review Rules page, click Create.

segment.source: The wizard will now create a set of rules allowing the installed set of apps.
segment.target: The wizard will now create a set of rules allowing the installed set of apps.

segment.source: Read the message and click Yes.
segment.target: Read the message and click Yes.

segment.source: default rules warning
segment.target: default rules warning

segment.source: (optional) If you want a rule to apply to a specific set of users, right-click on the rule and select Properties.
segment.target: (optional) If you want a rule to apply to a specific set of users, right-click on the rule and select Properties.

segment.source: Then use the dialog to choose a different user or group of users.
segment.target: Then use the dialog to choose a different user or group of users.

segment.source: (optional) If rules were generated for apps that should not be run, you can delete them by right-clicking on the rule and selecting Delete.
segment.target: (optional) If rules were generated for apps that should not be run, you can delete them by right-clicking on the rule and selecting Delete.

segment.source: Before AppLocker will enforce rules, the Application Identity service must be turned on.
segment.target: Before AppLocker will enforce rules, the Application Identity service must be turned on.

segment.source: To force the Application Identity service to automatically start on reset, open a command prompt and run:
segment.target: To force the Application Identity service to automatically start on reset, open a command prompt and run:

segment.source: Restart the device.
segment.target: Restart the device.

segment.source: Other settings to lock down
segment.target: Other settings to lock down

segment.source: In addition to specifying the apps that users can run, you should also restrict some settings and functions on the device.
segment.target: In addition to specifying the apps that users can run, you should also restrict some settings and functions on the device.

segment.source: For a more secure experience, we recommend that you make the following configuration changes to the device:
segment.target: For a more secure experience, we recommend that you make the following configuration changes to the device:

segment.source: Remove All apps.
segment.target: Remove All apps.

segment.source: Go to Group Policy EditorUser ConfigurationAdministrative TemplatesStart Menu and TaskbarRemove All Programs list from the Start menu.
segment.target: Go to Group Policy EditorUser ConfigurationAdministrative TemplatesStart Menu and TaskbarRemove All Programs list from the Start menu.

segment.source: Hide Ease of access feature on the logon screen.
segment.target: Hide Ease of access feature on the logon screen.

segment.source: Go to Control PanelEase of AccessEase of Access Center, and turn off all accessibility tools.
segment.target: Go to Control PanelEase of AccessEase of Access Center, and turn off all accessibility tools.

segment.source: Disable the hardware power button.
segment.target: Disable the hardware power button.

segment.source: Go to Power OptionsChoose what the power button does, change the setting to Do nothing, and then Save changes.
segment.target: Go to Power OptionsChoose what the power button does, change the setting to Do nothing, and then Save changes.

segment.source: Disable the camera.
segment.target: Disable the camera.

segment.source: Go to SettingsPrivacyCamera, and turn off Let apps use my camera.
segment.target: Go to SettingsPrivacyCamera, and turn off Let apps use my camera.

segment.source: Turn off app notifications on the lock screen.
segment.target: Turn off app notifications on the lock screen.

segment.source: Go to Group Policy EditorComputer ConfigurationAdministrative TemplatesSystemLogonTurn off app notifications on the lock screen.
segment.target: Go to Group Policy EditorComputer ConfigurationAdministrative TemplatesSystemLogonTurn off app notifications on the lock screen.

segment.source: Disable removable media.
segment.target: Disable removable media.

segment.source: Go to Group Policy EditorComputer ConfigurationAdministrative TemplatesSystemDevice InstallationDevice Installation Restrictions.
segment.target: Go to Group Policy EditorComputer ConfigurationAdministrative TemplatesSystemDevice InstallationDevice Installation Restrictions.

segment.source: Review the policy settings available in Device Installation Restrictions for the settings applicable to your situation.
segment.target: Review the policy settings available in Device Installation Restrictions for the settings applicable to your situation.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: To prevent this policy from affecting a member of the Administrators group, in Device Installation Restrictions, enable Allow administrators to override Device Installation Restriction policies.
segment.target: To prevent this policy from affecting a member of the Administrators group, in Device Installation Restrictions, enable Allow administrators to override Device Installation Restriction policies.

segment.source: To learn more about locking down features, see Customizations for Windows 10 Enterprise.
segment.target: To learn more about locking down features, see Customizations for Windows 10 Enterprise.

segment.source: Customize Start screen layout for the device
segment.target: Customize Start screen layout for the device

segment.source: Configure the Start menu on the device to only show tiles for the permitted apps.
segment.target: Configure the Start menu on the device to only show tiles for the permitted apps.

segment.source: You will make the changes manually, export the layout to an .xml file, and then apply that file to devices to prevent users from making changes.
segment.target: You will make the changes manually, export the layout to an .xml file, and then apply that file to devices to prevent users from making changes.

segment.source: For instructions, see Manage Windows 10 Start layout options.
segment.target: For instructions, see Manage Windows 10 Start layout options.
